channel.title: Morning Education
channel.description: Delivered every Monday by 10 a.m., Weekly Education examines the latest news in education politics and policy.

item.title: Why Americans say college isn’t worth the cost
item.description: Broad majorities of Americans say college simply costs too much and doesn’t provide enough benefits to be worth the effort — regardless of their political affiliation, age, and ethnicity.
item.dc:creator: By Juan Perez Jr.

item.title: Who could be left behind in ED split
item.description: The Trump administration’s planned teardown of the Education Department has raised concerns vulnerable students could be abandoned.
item.dc:creator: By Rebecca Carballo

item.title: The three attorneys general fighting to protect trans athletes
item.description: President Donald Trump’s administration has spent the year battling with three blue states over their discrimination protections for transgender athletes.
item.dc:creator: By Bianca Quilantan

item.title: The funding worry over school mental health services
item.description: President Donald Trump’s anti-DEI crusade, court fights and a record-breaking government shutdown have upended federal efforts to expand mental health services for young students.
item.dc:creator: By Juan Perez Jr.

item.title: What counts as professional?
item.description: The Education Department will continue rulemaking for various student loan programs today, even as the shutdown stretches past the one-month mark.
item.dc:creator: By Rebecca Carballo

item.title: Youngkin leaves a mark on Virginia’s university boards
item.description: How Virginia’s gubernatorial race shakes out next month could determine the longevity of Glenn Youngkin's efforts — especially the board appointments that were critical to implementing his higher education agenda.
item.dc:creator: By Bianca Quilantan

item.title: Colleges veto Trump's compact
item.description: The effort to coax universities into signing a higher education policy agreement is facing significant resistance.
item.dc:creator: By Juan Perez Jr.

item.title: Another round of staffing cuts
item.description: The Education Department, already hit by mass layoffs in March, is slated to lose another 466 within the offices that oversee special education programs, civil rights enforcement and provide services to HBCUs.
item.dc:creator: By Rebecca Carballo
